instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
This board was sent in as not turning on. The light on the charger stays green and it doesn't turn on when I hit the power button or when I short the onoff pads.

Here are some measurements I took before replacing the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> chip.

<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> 16.35 
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> - 4v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.58
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>- 3.41v
Resistance Pins 17/18 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - 2.9ohms
Resistance Pins 27/28 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - 20.2ohms
<CHIP>U5010</CHIP> voltages were all fine. 
shorted <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and saw the voltage go to 0v on <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> but still doesn't turn on
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (Pin 1 - 0v - Pin 6 - 0.78v - Pin 16 - 12.58v)
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
----------------------------------------

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> was showing 3.38v on pin 2 and 0v on the drain Pin 6 so I replaced the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>(<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>) 
There was still 0v on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> so I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>. Still made no difference.

I then checked Pin 16(VIN) of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and noticed it wasn't a stable 12.58v. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> starts off at 12.58v and quickly goes down to around 5v then jumps back up to 12.58v and repeats. I even took the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> off of the board and measured and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still does the same thing. 

What could be causing this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
SMC doesn't get <SIGNAL>3V_S5</SIGNAL> on time and resets <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> I suppose; duke explained this somewhere...
First of all, check resistance to ground on L6995; 200K resistance scale, not diode mode.
If get less than 30K trash the board; this means bad MCP almost all the time.
If seems to be good, check if VREGx outputs of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are steady.
Also check if any pulse appears at L7220.
If you remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>, both L7220/60 must get voltage; at least pulses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Resistance to ground on l6995 shows around 2.5Mohms
Pin 8 VREG3 - 0.73v and goes down. I think it shows 0.73 when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.58v
Pin 17 VREG5(<SIGNAL>P5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>) - around .35v and slowly goes down then comes back up

Pin 1 of L7220 is 1.07v when I first plug in charger then goes all the way down to 0.1v then back to 1.07v and repeats.

It sounds like I need to make <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> steady before anything else will work.

<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> pulses from 3.27 down to 3.11v. L7030 is 0.477 in diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message: <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was a stable 12.58 but there was no voltage on ENTRIP1 before I replaced the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> previously. After I replaced it thats when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> started fluctuating but even when I removed the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> from the board it was still fluctuating.

I have one more of these in my spool and I didn't want to waste the last one if that wasn't the issue. 

Should I go ahead and replace it again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
What kind of voltage are you searching at ENTRIP1?
The normal value (enabled) is 0.87V...
I suspect bad solders at new <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>; check for short on L7220/60 now.
Put back original chip and post some voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
I was always getting 0v on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7271</RESISTOR>.
With the replacement <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> on the board here is what I got.
L7220 in diode mode - 0.152v
L7260 in diode mode - 0.447v 

I put the original <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> on the board and the same thing is happening with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 0v on Pins 1/6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> 
L7220 in diode mode - 0.144v
L7260 in diode mode - 0.438v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
When <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is high, VREGx should appear too.
Is better to use o-scope to see if really rise their normal values; at least don't use auto-range multimeter...
If remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>, also should get voltages at L7220/60 at same time <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is high; if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is really high, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
I measured as soon as the charger was plugged in with my fluke 115 multimeter and pin 17 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> was 4.24v and it quickly goes down.
Pin 8 was 2.78v and it quickly goes down towards 0.6v then jumps back up to 2.78v and repeats.
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.4v.

These measurements are with the original <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Okay so I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is a steady 12.56v.

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> was still not getting steady voltage on the VDD Pin so I replaced the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> with a brand new one and still that didn't solve this.

Now when I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> there is 0v there, the resistance is around 95k and in diode mode <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 0.45v .
<CHIP>U7840</CHIP> voltages
Pin 1 - 3.4v     Pin 2 - 0v
Pin 3 - 0v        Pin 4 - 3.38v
Pin 6 - 0.98v   Pins 7/8 - 0v

Pins 8/17 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are still fluctuating and aren't at the proper voltages.

I'm sure this can be fixed because I fixed this this board for the customer a couple of weeks ago. It was not turning on so I replaced the DCIN board and it was working again. After a week they told me it would no longer turn on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Don't be so sure...
In the first DC board was fucked some resistor on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> line, which means overvoltage; maybe protection diode.
That could slightly affected SMC, which still worked, but now missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> could be result of that.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> first, if no light on magsafe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Do you know how <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> could be present before I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> but not anymore?
I have a green light on the magsafe.
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is 3.38v.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v
<CHIP>U5010</CHIP> measurements are fine.

I've tested with 2 know good dc-in boards.

Update: So I removed the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> from the board and plugged the charger in to see if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> would come on but it didn't and when I put the chip back on and plugged the charger in the light was dim green and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0.15v. I don't know what is going on. I've plugged in both DC-in boards and they both are dim green now.

2nd update: I looked around the SMC and found <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR> was corroded and in diode mode 0v to ground on both sides. I removed it and the pads are still 0v to ground in diode mode.
Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>(<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>) was also 0v to ground in diode mode. Removed <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> along with <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and still shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message: Crap under SMC? Shorted SMC? Inject voltage on 3V42 and see if anything heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
"So I removed the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> from the board and plugged the charger in"
So you may have to trash the board now.
I suppose one high-side MOSFET got burnt...
Never-ever power up a board leaving MOSFETs from a buck converter with the gate floating!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Okay I removed L6995 and the short was on Pin 2 side so I injected voltage there and the current was showing around 1 amps then it just started showing 0 amps and the short was gone. I put L6995 back on along with <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and now the green light is back.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is showing 12.58v then it will just go to 4v and quickly down to 3v then back to 12.58v for a couple seconds then repeats. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is back at 3.4v.
<CAPACITOR>C7273</CAPACITOR>(<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>) pulses from 4.7v and goes down.
<CAPACITOR>C7270</CAPACITOR>(<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG3</SIGNAL>) pulses from 3.33v and goes down as well.
I need to get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable as I did before. I'm not sure if these ISL6259s that I am getting from my spool are bad because I've replaced a few different ones and sometimes I get different voltages on PPBUS. 

Also, <RESISTOR>R5260</RESISTOR> is still showing 0v to ground in diode mode on both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> from a donor board and it is still fluctuating as I said previously. I also put flux and heated the SMC to rid of any corrosion under it and that still didn't solve this. Pins 17/18 27/28 resistance and traces are fine.
Any other ideas [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] ? I may have to refund the customer and send this back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground at L6995, in 200k scale.
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and tell us voltages at L7220/60 when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Red probe on Pin 1 of L6995 black on ground in resistance mode 200k scale shows 280kohms.
I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and measured.
L7220 was showing nothing but pulses of 0.05-0.13v.
L7260 was showing no voltage at all.

L7220 in diode mode was 0v to ground on both sides.
L7260 was 0.43v to ground on both sides.

Also now I am seeing 3.38v on Pin of <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> where before I was getting 0v on it.

Should I remove L7220 and see which side the short is on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
I'm wondering how can you read 280 value in a 200 scale...
You've probably used auto-range, not 200K selected.

Lift one pin of L7220 and look where the short is.
Be aware, this will not completely discard TPS!
Inject voltage starting with 1V, maybe less; keep the current under the limit of your lab supply.

The short appeared when you powered up the board without TPS; don't do that again...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message: I removed L7220. Pin 1 was showing 0.002v and Pin 2 was showing 0.07v in diode mode so I went to resistance mode to ground and Pin 2 was OL and Pin 1 was like 5ohms so I injected 1v into Pin 1 and couldn't feel anything getting warm so I went slowly up towards 2v(shows 2amps going through) and the only thing I feel getting warm is <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> and the opposite side of the board where <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> is. I put alcohol on those areas and nothing burned away unusually fast.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Okay I removed the thermal paste from the <CHIP>U1400</CHIP> chip and confirmed that it is getting really hot when I put 2.6v on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line. 

That means the chip would need to be replaced to fix this right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message:
Good luck to find a new MCP.
Is probably better to trash this board...
It still has more issues; not charging is not related with MCP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light, not turning on and not charging
threads.message: Okay thanks.
